title: Tuesday, 26th September, 2017

11:07 am
WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,399, down 24 (-1.69%), High: 1,402, Low: 1,385, Volume: 2.22m
PM11:08am

Is that on the back of Morgan Stanley?

BE11:08am

It is, and perhaps the broader question of "what the absolute hell is happening in advertising?"

11:08 am
BE11:09am

Folk with a memory long enough to remember yesterday will remember, if they choose to remember, the ITV stuff about September looking better .....

BE11:09am

..... which was on the idea of FMCG spend coming back.

BE11:10am

What we have today is MOST saying, actually, probably not tho.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Citing WPP on 'client pressure on costs'...

BE11:11am

Yup. This is on the back of WPP's second-quarter guidance so not new ... but tthey're talking structural pressure

BE11:11am

Guidance reduced, forecasts cut: WPP now targets FY17 organic net sales growth at zero to 1% (the target was at 3% in December and 2% in February). Q3 has July down 2.5% and August ‘a little bit more encouraging’. We look for Q3 down 1.5% with all three months in negative yoy net sales. We have Q4 up 0.9% (easier comp, AT&T loss annualises, Walgreens kicks in) bringing the year to -0.4%, behind WPP’s guidance. We have 15bps margin improvement for FY17 ( strong associates). In 2018 WPP net sales growth should benefit from an easier comp, better new business wins ($5.3bn to end July) and the mini quadrennial. Fee pressure and the slow feed of any improving environment to agency top line means we are low end with 0.5% organic net sales growth and 12bps of margin gain. We have 1.6%-2% pa net sales and 12-20bps of margin growth thereafter. Our eps forecasts drop 4% in 2017 and 8-12% 2018-20e.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

We think the industry slowdown is mainly the function of low GDP growth and the FMCG (and some other sectors) pressure on marketing expense. This has led to the associated procurement pressure on suppliers, including agencies, and some consequent price indiscipline among competing agencies. There’s structural mixed in as client distrust (the ANA report) has focused attention on how agencies make their money and particularly on media buying margins. We think though the role of the full service agency in the marketing value chain is robust, that digital (despite FB and Google) is a source of growth and that new competition from consultancies is limited.

BE11:12am

There is likely though to be no early resolution to the market’s structural fears over agencies. In the meantime Q3 for WPP looks weak and there may be fears over whether it can maintain its medium-term 10-15% eps growth target. If numbers hold (we are c4% below 2018 css eps of 128.8p) WPP is lowly rated at 1420p (11.7x 2017e p/e, FCF yield 9%, dividend yield 4.3%) but signs of a robust cyclical upturn are required to rebuild confidence.

PM11:12am

" client distrust"

11:12 am
PM11:13am

This an interesting theme -- advertising has always been so opaque

PM11:13am

And yes, there's the suspicion that digital advertising suffers from a lot of fraud...

BE11:14am

That reminds, there's one of those big and slightly nutty CLSA thematic things out this morning that covers online advertising.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Along with wafer fabrication trends, sociological issues linked to Facebook demographic models, and capitalism's thermal exhaust port. Honestly, I can't hope to summarise it here.

BE11:15am

Seriously. Random sample page.

PM11:15am

BE11:15am

BE11:15am

undefined
PM11:16am

11:16 am

We say, "back to trading statements", because that's what we do.

Card Factory PLC (CARD:LSE): Last: 302.90, down 52.1 (-14.68%), High: 340.00, Low: 289.00, Volume: 2.01m
PM11:17am

So is this a market structure issue and just a dreadful statement?

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Or both?

BE11:17am

Well, that's a good question. It's ........ an odd statement.

PM11:18am

Got a special divi in there that's done no good whatsoever

11:18 am
PM11:18am

https://www.invest...1709260700047663R/

BE11:18am

Yep, on one hand, you get a 15p special divi.

BE11:18am

On the other you get what might or might not be a warning on full-year margins

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Which is partly blamed on not passing through cost inflation

BE11:19am

But also some hedging noise and an increasing mix of not cards.

BE11:20am

In terms of what's happening to forecasts ........... nothing much.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

.... which is in part on the Q2 sales update, so only profitability was the missing element.

BE11:21am

Here's Morgan Stanley, again.

BE11:21am

- The outlook statement this morning seems fairly positive from a top-line perspective ("trading in recent weeks has been similar to the encouraging trends seen in the first half"). However it is less reassuring further down the income statement, with the company now guiding to EBITDA margins falling 200bps this year (vs previous guidance of 150bps), as result of pressures created by FX, product mix and the National Living Wage.
- The positive in today's statement, though, is that management has announced another 15p special dividend. Card Factory announced special dividends of 15p at each of its previous two sets of interim results, so this is unlikely to come as much of a surprise. Nevertheless we believe it will be welcomed by investors.
- We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but we would expect the revised EBITDA guidance to drive downgrades of c3% today to consensus forecasts. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for FY 2017/18 Pre Tax Profits of £85.5m (giving 20p of EPS)

11:22 am
BE11:23am

(@fjp73: on current trends, I estimate that fewer than 1% of those 12-35 year olds will be within that cohort within just 23 years.)

BE11:23am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:23am

Management’s rhetoric on dividend policy has spooked the
shares and they have now fallen to a highly attractive entry level.
Nothing that we have learned today changes our view on the
long-term future of the greetings card industry, or of Card
Factory. It has a peerless business model, which will put
continued inexorable pressure on the competition. The news is
that short-term profit progress will probably be harder than we
expected. But given the choice of strengthening its long-term
relative market position by investing in margin, or running the
business essentially for cash and short-term distributions, we
believe management is doing the right thing in dampening
“special” expectations. Of course it will be difficult for the shares
to do brilliantly given that short-term forecast momentum is now
flat, but Card Factory remains an excellent business and the
current share price now offers a great opportunity.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

On the divi guidance ....... which I have to admit I didn't read anything into ....

BE11:25am

We have always considered that the 15p special (confirmed for the third year running) was set in stone and actually should not be considered a special at all. This approach was too aggressive, and management is stating that whilst specials will undoubtedlly be a feature in the future, they should not be looked upon as an annual event, nor should 15p be seen as the standard number. The first question that we asked oursleves is “what does this tell us about the underlying business”. We will answer that in two ways: short and long term. In the immediate, it appears that management is not minded to put prices up. It has the competition under intense pressure, and is not loosening its grip. We felt that pricing was an opportunity: it appears that it isn’t, short term. So profit progession is likely to be lower in the next couple of years than we had hoped. What about the long term? Nothing has changed. Card Factory has by far the most effective business model in the sector, vertically integrated and obsessed with value for money. The continued strategy of placing the competition under maximum pressure may mean slightly less profit momentum short term, but will ensure a longer-term maintainance/improvement of its relative position. And that is, ultimately and despite the ugliness of the share price today, the right path for management to take. We are guilty of thinking that the job was done in becalming the competition. Our faith in Card Factory as a cash-generative “winner” is unchanged, and consider the shares to be very interesting in the early 3s. On a now biennial special, they still yield 6%.

BE11:26am

Analysts there are Jonathan Pritchard and John Stevenson. Apologies for over-quoting, but they put forward their argument so well it undermines all attempts to summarise.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Have Investec as well. Just for the full set.

BE11:27am

Forecast changes: In light of revised guidance, we cut PBT by 5% in FY18e and 7.5% in FY19e. From a dividend perspective, we reduce ordinary dividend cover to 2.1x (was 2.2x), which would allow for continued ordinary dividend growth.
Capital structure: The biggest change surrounds messaging on future capital returns. Whilst CARD is still looking at maintaining 1-2x ND/EBITDA leverage, looking ahead management is flagging that leverage is starting to increase given the anticipated profit decline this year. We cut our future surplus capital returns to 10p/share, with gearing at c. 1.6x in FY19e (vs. 1.8x if returned 15p).
Valuation (c.16x CY18e PE) is at a premium to peers reflecting its high margins and cash generative capabilities. However, the limited profit growth profile near-term and uncertainty as to the quantum and extent of surplus capital returns reduces upside near-term. Down to HOLD from Buy, TP lowered to 320p.

BE11:27am

And that'll do for cards.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Indeed

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:30 am
PM11:30am

hmm. dunno

BE11:30am

Anyway, results are fine but the beat against consensus is thanks to a £7.5m provision release.

BE11:31am

So otherwise, it's a bit uninspiring.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

You have that provision keeping the impairment charge at 0.6% rather than 0.7%, which would've been a 15% deterioration (though still a very small number in the context of the sector, of course).

BE11:32am

Numis likes everything about Close except the valuation.

BE11:33am

We continue to believe that Close is the specialist lender to own through the cycle that we see as having turned. Close is not expensive being valued at 11.8x the 128.3p of earnings just reported.
● The model: The core banking business has a long and successful track record, growing rapidly when risk is lowest and margins are highest, losing market share when margins are lowest and risk is highest. Close is constantly looking for and investing in new high risk adjusted margin, specialist lending market segments that do not lend themselves to competition from commodity capital. Consequently, the economic profit is consistently and sustainably high, but growth can be volatile as it is an output variable as opposed to an input variable. Underwriting discipline saw the ROE bottom at 13.2% at the worst point of the credit crisis and Close has a 31 year EPS CAGR of 11%, having never cut the dividend or had a rescue rights issue.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Hold, target 1,575p.

PM11:33am

Impairment charges at 0.6% feel suspiciously low to me

PM11:33am

This is retail finance -- yeah? Including cars...

11:34 am
PM11:34am

They may be disciplined in their lending criteria, but still

BE11:34am

Motor is an area highlighted in the statement

BE11:34am

Barclays:

11:34 am
BE11:34am

CLOSE BROTHERS (EW, PT 1550P) FY17 (Jul YE) underlying operating profit of £265m is up 13% yoy and a 2% beat vs our forecast of £260m. The beat is mainly driven by Winterflood where operating profits came in at £28m vs our forecast of £25m, from improvement in trading activity, whereas Banking and Asset Mgmt operating profits of £243.5m and £17.4m respectively were in line. Adjusted basic EPS of 131.7p is a 1% beat vs Barclays f/c 130.2p, up 5% yoy, and DPS of 60p vs our 57.5p expectation. Loan book is up 7% yoy to £6.9bn, which was already expected after reaching £6.8bn at the Jun pre close. This was driven mainly Property Finance book which grew 12% to £1.6bn, supplemented from growth in the smaller divisions Invoice and Premium finance whereas Asset Finance and Motor Finance books were broadly flat, as management “prioritize strict lending criteria in the face of continued competition”. NIM is 8.1% down from 8.2% last year due to mix, and the bad debt ratio is down from 0.7% to 0.6%. Group ROE is down slightly yoy, from 19% to 18%, due to first year of the full effect of the 8% Bank tax surcharge. The business remains well capitalized at a 12.6% CET1 ratio. Management outlook is cautious, saying the current market conditions are stable but longer-term economic outlook and Brexit impact are uncertain. The competitive environment remains challenging in the Motor and Asset Finance business, in particular PCP which is 15% of their Motor Finance book or ~4% overall book, so they continue to monitor demand and credit performance carefully. Winterflood’s good performance has continued but remains sensitive to market conditions and in Asset Mgmt they are pleased with their progress and remain focused on growing the business in the long term. The shares have outperformed modestly ytd up 6% vs FTSE Allshare +2%. We find valuation undemanding at ~11.5x cal 2018 PE or 2.1x historical P/BV.

BE11:35am

And I guess that's that. Next year looking a bit tough, shares down.

11:39 am

BE11:40am

I guess we'll have to see what he does when he notices the balance sheet. In the meantime, here's Barclays.

BE11:40am

his first act to prolong the period of IT implementation is probably a sensible one, albeit it incremental capex to FY19e, hence the inflection in FCF will not be as pronounced as we currently forecast. The roadside business has held retention at 82%, despite IPT, dual-cover and FCA disclosure headwinds, and the influx in new business has naturally lowered average revenue per member in 1H18. We take encouragement from this improvement in KPIs but note uncertainty still looms over the size of the ‘additional investment’ which may be required once the CEO completes his review of the business.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

And Citi.

BE11:41am

Implications — The 1H17 results are slightly softer than the trading update earlier this summer (1st August). Despite the slightly lower EBITDA guidance, we expect the market will be looking for any strategic comments made by the new permanent CEO, Simon Breakwell, at the analyst briefing. However we expect a more thorough strategic review will be delivered around the FY18e results.

11:51 am

undefined
BE11:52am

@ROTR, apologies if you've made a request, it didn't register.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Feel free to make it again, though your experience might be similar.

BE11:53am

In the meantime, what can get us to midday?

BE11:53am

There's EasyJet .....

11:54 am
BE11:54am

.... which is on the Air Berlin breakup

BE11:55am

Lufthansa and Easy are the only two bidders left in the auction, which runs until October 12 for some reason.

BE11:55am

EasyJet likely take over parts of AB’s operation in Berlin and Dusseldorf.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Which is good, according to SocGen.

BE11:56am

Berlin is a fast-growing market, and slots should also be a scarce resource over the upcoming years, due to the bad planning for the new airport. Dusseldorf is Germany’s airport with the biggest catchment area (and AB’s second hub), and therefore it is also attractive to take over an operation with good slots there.

BE11:57am

(Doesn't Berlin have a big airport to the north and a wee one to the south, plus a third one that's now left for Frisbee tournaments and dog walking? Didn't strike me as hugely tight in terms of capacity, but dunno.)

11:57 am
PM11:57am

(Never been)

BE11:57am

...... plus we have a UBS evidence lab thing.

BE11:58am

(Go to Berlin. It's properly great, though it's so large it's unwieldy.)

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Cross purchase analysis shows that easyJet's customer base overlaps more with Ryanair's than does BA's, which in our view is as expected. In addition, easyJet is also more of a substitute for BA. (Note that Ryanair is viewed as more of a substitute for easyJet than BA.) Accordingly, we think easyJet (rated Buy) will benefit from recent roster issues that Ryanair has faced given the high levels of substitution.

BE11:59am

The UBS Evidence Lab data suggests that total airline spend is up slightly (~1%) over the last twelve months. BA seems to be capturing most of the increase as spend is up ~5% year-over-year, whereas easyJet and Ryanair are down ~6% and ~1% respectively (likely due to pricing). We expect that BA continues to benefit from fare mix between long haul and short haul as well as premium vs economy passenger seats.

BE11:59am

Concerns about a UK consumer aviation spend slowdown is not evident. We see evidence that in aggregate purchase incidence has been relatively flat over the last 2 years to June 2017, with c32% of UK consumers spending greater than £10 across all three airlines during each of the 12 month periods (Circa 24% of consumers made purchases totaling at least £100 with the airlines). At our UBS Travel conference in September the European airlines under our coverage confirmed an in-line to better summer travel season.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

We also look at the incidence of total spend for 12 month spend of more than £10 and £100 beginning from June 2015 for the individual airlines. The market share data shows easyJet as the top UK airline by incidence spend followed by Ryanair and then BA. Overall purchase incidence has held flat year-over-year. Incidence for the most recent quarter (2017 Q2) is down quarter-over-quarter (i.e., compared to 2017 Q1), but this appears to be the usual seasonal pattern. We rate easyJet Buy and see the Capital Market's Day on 27th September as a positive catalyst for the shares.

BE12:00pm

So, there.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 16.45, up 0.09 (+0.55%), High: 16.49, Low: 16.26, Volume: 689.22k
